results.title: Living room
results.brief_description: A catalogue of assorted Sydneysiders pose for the camera “at home”. A photographic mosaic of faces and places, Living Room exposes the myths surrounding home ownership and the shrinking potential of home ownership and reveals surprising values and attitudes. The program raises questions about the lack of services and isolation associated with outer suburban life. It looks at our treatment of the elderly and the way the nuclear family and the dream of “owning your own home” have shaped our living environment.

results.title: Living reptile: the locomotion of snakes
results.creator_credit: New York Zoological Society and James A. Oliver
results.brief_description: This study of snake locomotion opens by showing the typical four-legged method of locomotion of animals and how it is related to the serpentine motion of the snake. Described in detail are the serpentine motion, employed by all snakes; the caterpillar motion used by some such as the Reticulated Python and the Puff Adder; the side-winding motion used chiefly by heaby-bodied desert snakes, and the hitch-and-hike or concertina method used by some snakes in climbing trees.
results.creator_credit_for_label: New York Zoological Society and James A. Oliver

results.title: Living outback on a farm
results.creator_credit: Donald Batchelor, ABC-TV (Australia) and Nandor Jenes
results.brief_description: Presents a view of life on a wheat farm in the Australian outback. Shows farming activities and indicates the necessity of a good water supply. Also shows the nearby town, local school and a picnic.

results.title: Living jazz
results.creator_credit: BFI, Paddy Whannel, John Hall and Jack Gold
results.brief_description: A candid study of the Bruce Turner Jump Band at work, at individual and group practice rehearsal, on tour and as they discuss and arrange their music. Music written and arranged by Bruce Turner. Instruments: Bruce Turner (Alto Sax), John Mumford (Trombone), Johnny Chilton (Trumpet), Colin Bates (Piano), Jim Bray (Bass), Johnny Armitage (Drums). Presented by Doug Dobell and Ken Lindsay.

results.title: Living in the dark
results.brief_description:
Using 2-D animation this short film captures the filmmaker’s childhood experience of an eye injury which not only caused a temporary loss of sight and distortion of vision, but also a sense of fear and loneliness. His father too suffered a similar fate as a child but circumstances were such that he became permanently blind. The story explores family relationships and reflects on life’s unexpected turns. Narrated by Roberto Salvatore.

“Living in the dark” recently won the best cinematography in the 2005 Bondi Short Film Festival in Sydney and was selected for the Electronic Theatre Program at the Graphite 2005 Conference, Dunedin, New Zealand.

results.title: Living in Scotland = The Smiths in Scotland
results.creator_credit: International Film Associates (Scotland), Films of Scotland and Laurence Henson
results.brief_description: A presentation of the virtues of Scotland and its people. Roots and tradition are still important but change and development is offering new skills and resources to the world. Covers Scotland’s countryside, cities, universities, industries and its sporting opportunities, especially water sports as no part of Scotland is more than 50 miles from the water. Narrated by Bryden Murdoch.

results.title: Living in memory
results.brief_description: Ray Barrett delivers a potted history of Australia at war, via the exhibits in the Australian War Museum. The film begins in the 1890s and continues through to the Vietnam war mentioning aspects of the Boer War, World War I including Gallipoli, World War II, and the wars in Korea, North Borneo and Malaysia.

results.title: Living in a metropolis: Greater New York
results.creator_credit: Louis De Rochemont and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
This film describes New York City; population 9,000,000 (1949). Aerial views of the city and harbour, its office buildings etc show briefly its general appearance. A gateway to the United States from the East, it is a terminus for shipping, a railroad centre and has three airports. Film also includes glimpses of Park Avenue, Harlem, Chinatown, the housing projects, subways, bridges, tunnels, the food markets, restaurants, the banks on Wall Street, the garment industry and departmental stores, Central Park, Coney Island and Times Square.
